reviewText:
Brian and his "roommate" Dennis have endured years of southern Sunday dinners with Brian's widowed mother, Mae, and his Aunt Rose.  Both of the women are  equally clueless about the fact that they are a gay couple, and constantly invite along a single woman for Brian to meet.  When Dennis and Brian break up, Brian shows up for dinner alone, explaining his "roommate" found his own place, and is further upset when that evening's female guest figures him out in a matter of minutes. Mae and Rose overhear her remark that Brian is gay, and, after some soul searching, they decide to find a new boyfriend for him.  They go to a local gay bar, and talk a go-go boy into coming for Sunday dinner.  When Brian brings along a guest they were not expecting, luckily Mae and Rose have other guests who come to the rescue.

This is a madcap, over-the-top comedy, kind of in the same vein as "Sordid Lives," complete with Southern accents that come and go. There are liberal doses of camp and stereotypes, drag queens, internet hook-up sites, ageist twinks, leather people, bible thumping, an ex-gay conversion center (complete with shock therapy), and an overall implausible premise that you want to believe anyway, because it is just so darned much fun.  Positive depictions of gay youth, and lessons to parents who don't accept their gay or lesbian children, are valuable parts of the story.  Written/directed and produced by Keith Hartman, best known for several (equally "over-the-top") gay novels, on a tiny budget that he put to excellent use (Many of the extras in the bar scene are actually crew members.)  Unrated, but would be PG for light sexual content. DVD extras listed include commentaries by Hartman (which doesn't work on my retail DVD) or by the actresses who played the two women, a go-go boy video, deleted scene, trailer and cast/crew profiles.  Won several gay film festival awards with its infectious positive humor.  I give it four stars out of five.

A very cute, over-the-top comedy with a subtle message of acceptance and unconditional love. You Should Meet My Son is a lighthearted movie, with a much deeper, underlying moral. I loved the shift in the mother's behavior from beginning to end. Watching her go from denial over her son's sexuality, to begrudging acceptance, and then finally fully embracing him as is was a beautiful thing. We should all be so lucky as to have a parent who can cast aside a lifetime's worth of ingrained beliefs and prejudices in order to encourage and support their child.

An understanding mom decides to fix her closeted son up with a hot guy to show her support for his life choices. While looking for the right man for her son she collects an eclectic group of friends Her son comes home with a woman and announces he's engaged. But Mom knows what's best for her boy and sabotages the engagement by introducing the future in-laws to her new friends.

Funny, poignant, entertaining and enlightening, 'You Should Meet My Son' is a small budget movie featuring big budget talent from an incredible cast and stupendous script to delightful direction.

Definitely a must see.

I saw the film at a festival screening.  The movie provides a delightfully humorous view on potentially socially unpleasant or awkward situations.  Sometimes you have to laugh at what life throws at you.  This film produced nearly non-stop belly laughs while still getting across an important point about families, coming out, and being true to yourself and your values.

If non-stop, shrieking fake Southern accents, garish stereotypes, and humor as subtle as being hit in the head with a cast iron frying pan send you rolling in the aisles, then you will probably love this movie. I was raised in a subtler, less obnoxious South than the one celebrated here, and I am too happy being gay to relate to this hysteria, so I hated it.

But any gay movie that celebrates being gay deserves some support, so I gave it two stars just for having its heart in the right place. God bless it, its makers, and anybody who can enjoy it.

This delightful, gay-themed, screwball comedy of errors makes a perfect gay date night movie.  Joanne McGee and Carol Goans as the stand-outs as the two sisters who conspire to get their gay son/nephew a date.  This could have been a one joke wonder but the plot manages to get more engaging right through the end of the third act.  You do have to overlook the production problems that come with a low budget indie, such as people speaking off mic or the character of the neighbor boy whose name we never hear until his second appearance.  Brian, the son/nephew who needs a date, happily doesn't get too much screen time, since  he's horribly miscast for the part and never earns much sympathy from the audience. The best scene is in Act 1 when mom tries to pair gay Brian up with a Suzanne, straight lawyer. Jaclyn Napier's energetic and polished performance gives a strong opening to movie. Too bad her character disappears after the first scene.  The movie does rely heavily on easy laughs from the usual gay and homophobic stereotypes but at least we're spared the gay tragedy storylines that only indie film critics seem to love: hate crime (Brokeback Mountain), terminal illness (Philadelphia, Jeffrey) and self-loathing (Boys in the Band).  Like the classic, screwball comedies from other eras, this is an old fashioned film with a contemporary theme that will keep you smiling for 90 minutes.

I read the 1 and 2 star reviews about how this movie was low budget, without powerful acting, and that too much was unbelievable. What's unbelievable is the people who gave those reviews. How often do you see major studios spending major bucks and hiring major actors to do a movie covering a subject like this? Not very often at all. They're just now getting comfortable having it on TV. The reviewers mention "To Wong Foo" and "Brokeback"; those movies are 10 years apart! You shouldn't have to wait that long to see a decent movie addressing a real life issue, because that's what it is, real life. So yes, this was low budget and filled with actors probably no one's seen or heard of, and no, there weren't any stellar, breakout performances. But I thought it was cute, it was sweet, and it had its funny moments. And it shows how a mother SHOULD act if and when her child comes out: with love and support. The best line in the movie was when she told her son that if the world wouldn't give him what he wanted, then she would change the whole world because she would never change him. (Yes, I almost cried.) It is pricey but I enjoyed it and don't regret watching it. The only thing I would've changed, I would have liked to see things working out between Brian & Chase, maybe a few months down the road. What can I say? I'm a sucker for epilogues and HEAs.

I found this film to be fantastic. That it is not well known is both a curiosity and a shame. While staying out of the too-raunchy zone, something I thought was inevitable with its NR rating, it displays a sense of humor that anyone can appreciate. The lovable plot reveals the confusing and difficult life of a gay person, and helps reinforce it with its rural Alabama setting. The immediate acceptance and continuance of the lovable mother's interference in her sons life shows just how far family should go to ensure happiness, and is a good response to her son's sexuality. Finally, removing the stigma from homosexuality and humanizing some of the "stand out gays" in the film create pleasant and funny characters. I enjoyed this film thoroughly, and my only problem with it is that it wasn't long enough.

What I do appreciate about this film more than anything, is it's very accurate depiction of the rudeness of "twinks" toward older gay men and how gay bar crowds can come across as being very anti-social to anyone new or "different" from the typical bar ccustomers.

If you love Auntie Mame with Rosalind Russell, you'll appreciate the loving homage that this indie pays to a scene in that  marvelous 1958 film.  This movie's denouement is a wonderful reinterpretation that classic scene during which Mame Dennis fantastically derails the engagement of her beloved Patrick Dennis to the ghastly Gloria Upson.  Only in this film, the betrothal derailment is accomplished not with pickled rattlesnake and flaming cocktails, but with flaming drag glamazons and a nude portrait of George Herbert Walker Bush.  No. Joke.

While this film is set in Birmingham, AL, the actors' accents were inconsistent.  I know this fact because I grew up in Alabama.  The actors portraying the aunt and mother gave good approximations of the accents of educated, upper-middle-class, Alabama females of (about) age 60.  The son and the rest of the cast were less spot-on.

In summary, I laughed aloud, several times.  What more could you want on a Christmas afternoon?
This is a great movie. I'll definitely watch this over probably a few times. Just love the Mother that goes out of her way to find her son Mr. Right, lol. Must see. Thanks.
So yes, it's cheaply made (and obviously so) and the acting is over the top, but it's still a fun movie. It made me laugh and even made me a little teary. Over all it's worth the $2 to rent.

If your looking for a cute, feel good movie, I highly recommend this film. Throw in a few drag queens, a bible thumping family, some internet dating, southern charm and a a mother who will go to EXTREME lengths to see her son happy and you develop the crazy cast of characters that makes this film funny, heartwarming and just all around fun to watch.
There aren't many like this. I laughed and laughed. It was very unexpected. Reminds me of the classics like Butch Camp.

Such a charming little movie. I laughed so hard I almost cried, and then was brought to tears by a touching scene in the next moment. And how wonderful that this "gay" movie actually focuses on the mother and aunt. Not perfect by any means -- some of the scenes take a huge leap of faith to follow the story -- but that only adds to the delight. Rent this one!

I found this short movie to be original and funny. The lengths these two women go through to help find their son/nephew a husband after finding out he's gay is amazingly humorous. Definitely one of the best LGBT themed movies out there.
Great movie! Funny! The girls just cracked me up! I had a great time seeing this one! Cute at the same time, it's also a good movie with an important message to learn from.
This is a great movie. I wish they would make a second movie I would like to see what happens next.

This is a great movie. I actually loved the two older women they make the movie vary funny. Yes, its a gay film but its a good one, no nudity. However, the movie starts out slow but it gets funny quick and I think it also teaches a lesson in a funny way.
Smart funny dialog and good acting in this low-budget yet still excellent movie.  Will also uplift your heart at the same time it is tickling your funny bone - it is a laugh out loud movie.
A bit formulaic and it kinda falls apart towards the end, but a fun movie.  I would recommend it for a funny grown-up movie.... not for kids.

Fun, entertaining and easy on the eyes. This movie has it all. Steve Snyder as the hunky go-go boy with a heart is a dream! You'll re-watch his dancing a few times I guarantee! Joanne McGee and Carol Goans as the Mom and Aunt are amazing! When they discover ManHunt?! Priceless!
Bottom line is this is a feel good movie you'll be glad you took the time to watch.

It's hard to find a really good LGBT movie. This is one of those rare gems. It's low budget so the settings are modest, but the plot and the acting are amazing. It's a comedy that pokes fun at stereotypes, so characters may be a little over-the-top or downright ridiculous at some points, but that's what adds to the appeal. I rented this movie because I didn't think I'd like it, but now I think I'm going to buy it. It's a keeper.

I must say, I was a little skeptical about buying this movie on DVD, but now that I have watched it I definitely recommend this movie! :) It is funny, beautiful, tender, serious yet not to ferocious and a wonderful movie of what Love really is, that is transcends hate and insecurity.

A feel good comedy about coming out towards your parents and meeting their expectations.
Not the best quality, but worthwhile anyway. Enjoy!
Funny...hilarious actually! And of course it has the heartwarming message towards the end of the film. Do yourself a favor and buy it!

Literally left me in tears. What an excellently done gay film. And a PG13 FAMILY gay film at that. I would have no problem watching this film with kids who can Grease. Reminded me how amazing having a parent who loves you can be. I HIGHLY recommend this movie, it most definitely needs more recognition. Loved it.

This movie is entertaining without the usual "skin" that is shown to keep a movie interesting.  The mother and aunt characters are played very well.  The supporting cast is an eclectic group of interesting people.  Overall I enjoyed the movie.

This is a cute movie. It has a great message & I enjoyed it far more than I usually do with these types of films. No swearing or nudity (don't let the cover fool you) so it's safe for anyone of any age. Give it a watch--you might like it too.

Great Movie as I was in stitches through the hole thing.
Very funny Movie.
If you want to laugh, then this is the movie for you to watch.

I can't say enough about this movie! It's about a Southern Mom who spends the beginning of the movie parading prospective wives for her single son. She then discovers he's gay. Her journey from that discovery to her acceptance is right on the mark. I should know since I am an only child in a Sicilian family. Unfortunately, my mother didn't have the tenacity to work through her discovery to acceptance (though she finally resigned herself to the fact). This movie showed how it could be, how it should be! Aside from all this, the movie is well-written and hilarious! Joanne McGee, the Mom, was perfect as she tried to adjust her life to this new world, and she was absolutely exhilarating and uproariously funny. However, Carol Goans, who plays Aunt Rose, simply stole the show! I won't say more, but whether this situation applies to your own life, and even if it doesn't, this is a movie well worth viewing!! I can't wait to watch it again!! You Should Meet My Son!

I watched this movie with my mother, we come from a rather religious family and things have been difficult since the beginning. We laughed and talked through the whole movie and we both loved it. It couldn't have brought us any closer.

Don't believe the reviews here. The reviews have to be a scam to get you to watch because this movie is awful. Over-acted and over-wrought!  The movie's first half-hour showed promise but then the movie quickly fell apart once the mother and her sister visited a gay club.  The plot stalled and the story became predictable and dull. Once the sister gets made over in a bathroom by 2 drag queens, (while the mother inexplicably doesn't even seem fazed by her sister's prolonged absence in an unfamiliar place), I stopped watching. I have to comment on a glaring inconsistency.  In the beginning, there is a parade of different girls invited over to dinner, representing all the times that the mother and the aunt had tried in vain to do some match-making for the son (who was secretly gay). The clothing for the mother, aunt and the different girls always changes from one attempt to another. With each attempt, they show the son and his boyfriend seated at the table. However, in error, their clothing never changes. It should have. Speaking of changes, this film needed a much, much better production team!
this is a wonderful movie about a mother that loves her son more than cares about sticking to the rules. it's just wonderful how the movie plays out. the mother and aunt are fantastic. a must see!!!

This movie started out very slow - and with the odd stilted acting that you see on the stage, very theatrical, and in the specific style you might see at an off-Broadway show.  After getting over the over the top performances of the Southern mother and her sister, the sort-of unbelievable naivete that they exhibit going online to see what Manhunt is about and going to their town's gay bar, I started to actually like the movie.

It is most certainly NOT of the same standard as a movie like Trick, but it is good.  The parts that start to bring the drag queens and muscle-leather couple and the young 16 yr old gay neighbor kid together start to feel even more like Spanish Golden Age Theater or Oscar Wilde style of surprise-shock of unexpected conversations and interactions.

The end of the movie was tender, showing the total love and support the mother has always had, and the dreams she has for his happiness.  If you're expecting a high-gloss film with very high movie-type standards, this is not for you.  If you are more relaxed about those expectations, then you should enjoy the film as much as I ended up enjoying it.

i found this movie to be most enjoyable and a pleasure to watch. sure the title says meet my son but it is more about the mother and aunt in this movie and thru the love for son/nephew they come to learn and blossom themselves.

So just watch the trailer for it, it is HILARIOUS. I HAD to have it and you just can't find it cheaper than the $20 sadly... That being said, I don't really buy movies, let alone spend $20 on one! This on though, i'd spend that again because this is the best heartfelt movie i've seen in a long time. Its HILARIOUS and pretty much unrealistic how accepting the mom and aunt are but you don't really care. It makes me cry every time when the mom tells her son that she will change the world for him if they can't accept him the way he is and give him what he wants. A love like that is just amazing. I watched it with my boyfriend and mom and all three of us laughed our butts off and cried of course. =) Get it, you won't regret it!
My partner and I just watched this film and we laughed our a*ses off!  Wonderful move. Definitely a must see!

One of the best gay movies I've seen. Didnt care for the shock therapy scenes. Took matters a little too lightly there but otherwise a wonderful film to watch with the family. Very great conversation starter!
just a good movie... I admit the quality isn't great but I loved the message... had me laughing and smiling throughout the entire movie
it was funny caring and maybe not a situation most gays would find themselves in but maybe a desirable one!

No matter what these 4 star reviews on Amazon say this film is very poorly made and seems like a high school play.  Harsh lighting, sound that that is not mixed necessitating adjusting the volume over and over. Strident delivery from the actresses playing the mother and aunt. A truly embarssing scene in a gay bar that is played against one wall as if there really was no set. And the ending sequence was just a confusing mish mash with everything shot from one angle in the livingroom like a tableau or stage play. In fact in the final moment between the mother and son she literally escorts him downstage closer to the camera to play their final moments. Very odd. In fact lots of scenes were played out with no coverage--just a single shot with two or three characters standing and reciting their lines.  I can only assume that friends of the director or the production are posting these extremely misleading complimentary reviews.  The director touts this as a "micro-budget movie".  Indeed it is.  A lamentable product of an unfortunate phase in indie films.

It's a sweet and entertaining idea for a movie in a weak production. The acting is "community theater" level and serviceable.
The point of view is flawed. We start with  the son's point of view, then a little late in we're switched to his mother and aunt's pov.  The actor playing the son is better than the rest so he steals the scenes he's in, perhaps that's the issue. The film gives us the adventures of the mom and her sister. Unbeknownst to son, they've learned he is gay. They quickly transition from firmly against to full acceptance then set off to find him a boyfriend to replace the one he's just lost. It all appears to happen in the span of a few days, which is unreasonable for the outcomes.
I thought the premise, many segments and a lot of the dialogue were entertaining, even touching. The moms zany character is infectious and the theme that over all she loves her son and wants to find him happiness is engaging. I'd actually love to see these characters and this plot, even some of the script after some skilled filmmaking.
This is such a kitsch little film! Campy, crazy re-imagination of family. Lifted my mood! The passive aggressive Southern culture was great! Love!

Very entertaining movie where a mother who's been trying to fix her son up with girls, finds out her son is gay and goes on a search to find him a companion.  Had funny parts in it like going to a gay go go bar and the drag queens.
It was a great movie me & my mom watched this & loved the entire movie but it just didn't end right & im hoping there be a part 2 of this...
Was a little skeptical at first, but after watching it that all changed. A little campy at times, but this camp just adds to the charm of the movie. I'll consider purchasing this one.

This was a really funny film that was also very uplifting, positive, and heartwarming.  It's not going to win any oscars (the acting is a bit over the top in places) but it's definitely worth renting and even having in your gay movie collection.  The mom and aunt are freekin hilarious.  Check it out, you won't be sorry.
Movie start off slow, but hang on for the end. It is funny yet heart warming. So worth watching. That being said, if the LGBT lifestyle offends you, find something else to watch.

Does anyone else see the 'Auntie Mame' references in this movie? or is it just me? Either way, I found it delightfully funny, campy, and sweet. It may not win any awards for best 'Gay' themed movie of the year, but it certainly made me laugh, and is that what comedies are supposed to do?

I really was not expecting much when I rented this movie. I was delightfully surprised at how good it turned out to be. The beginning is a bit rough, but, after it gets going, the movie gets so much better. Only if real life mimicked the movies instead of the other way around...

Very good movie! I love both the Mother and the Aunt in this film! I would say I wish I had a mother that would do the same, but than that might be pushing it. It just goes to show how far a mother's love will travel.

This is another gay comedy and the more the merrier I say. This is one with a twist though as the central characters are the mother and auntie of our central gay character. He is Brian (Stewart Carrico) and is the only son, of Mae (Joanne McGee). She is a Southern Belle type of mom that Tennessee Williams could have written odes about. She lives with her sister, Aunt Rose (Carol Goans).

Their raison d'tre of their entire existence is to get Brian married off to the sweetest little, southern gal and start popping out sweet, little, southern babies. This they do by inviting Brian to dinner and just happening to have also invited an eligible spinster from their wide coterie of friends. Brian always brings his `house mate' Dennis and despite the obvious chemistry between the two men, they just don't get it.

Well Dennis finally leaves Brian and discovers his Mr Right. Mother and Auntie then accidentally discover the awful truth that he is - `you know - one of them!' Well after they have gotten used to the idea they decide that they love him just the way he is and set about using their extensive dinner making skills and womanly charms to get him a gay man.

Their first port of call is the local gay bar and discorama, which is one of those clubs that has a bit of everything, go go dancer, leather fetish, twinks, drag queens etc. They seem to take to it like a pair of ducks to water and the fun begins.

This is a warm comedy and though gay themed there is nothing here that would offend anyone, some cross dressing and no man on man action, as the stars here are the mum and aunt and they really do steal the show especially Joanne McGee who is a tour de force of good intentions - road to hell type woman.

Keith Hartman wrote and directed this and it is a brilliant effort. He has managed to get great performances and a good quality production from what was obviously a limited budget as the sound is a bit ropey in places, but that is entirely forgivable. I laughed on a number of occasions and it left me wanting more. So I watched all the extras and there are three excellent short films from Mr Hartman and some `Gratuitous Go Go Boy Footage'. All in all an enjoyable light hearted comedy that deals with all the issues in a caring way but with enough challenges to stop it from getting too schmaltzy. Not the best film ever but I really enjoyed it and hope you will too.

I can't recommend this movie enough. One of the best laughs I've had in a long time. Well worth the time and money. If you liked Sordid Lives, you'll love this. I could see so many people I have met over the years in this movie.

You Should Meet My Son is a great movie.  Wonderful acting; the chemistry between the actors is a joy to watch.  Wonderful script.  Incredible production value for a low-budget indie film.  It is both funny and heartwarming, and manages to be just a touch over the top without ever feeling unreal. (It read so true that I found myself wanting to go to Alabama and meet all these wonderful people.)

It was a great pleasure, too, to see a film starring women who are middle-aged and (mostly) comfortable with it.

Although the central issue is Mae coping with discovering that her son is guy, and growing to accept this, then finding him a life partner, You Should Meet My Son is so much more than "a gay movie". It's about family (the one you came with and the one you build for yourself).  It's about caring for people as they are, and working to make the world better for everyone.  It's about seeing through your prejudices to the real people below and learning to live with difference (and one of the great things about the film is that it does this, presenting even the unsympathetic and prejudiced characters with understanding).  Also just a little bit about both accepting yourself and about letting your hair down and learning to enjoy life.

When our closeted hero breaks up with his boyfriend, his clueless Southern mother throws a collection of young women at him.  When mom overhears the last in a long line of young women inadvertently out her boy, she starts on a hunt to find him a proper new boyfriend.  Mayhem ensues, culminating in a hysterical dinner party that is a copy of the one in Auntie Mame where Mame is sabotaging her nephew's relationship with his unsuitable girlfriend.  The ending is a little predictable, but the whole movie is so charming, with parts of it being laugh-out-loud funny, that you don't mind.  The characters are believable and engaging and immensely likeable, (well, except for the Bible-thumping bigots but they are hysterically funny.)  Drag queens, go-go boys, leathermen are all part of the delightful mix.  And unlike many of these independent gay comedies, the acting is quite good and reasonably convincing.  This is a charming gay comedy even your straight friends would find funny--well, at least the liberal-minded would!

If you liked Torchsong Trilogy, To Wong Fu, Priscilla Queen of the Dessert or Broke Back Mountain, then you are in for a big disappointment with this film. To me, it was just moderately funny at best and has no real substance. I guess it's amusing that you could find two totally accepting women living in the Bible Belt, who are just thrilled that their son and nephew is gay, but other than that, it is just too unbelievable and doesn't make much sense.

The subject of the story, the young man in question is so lack luster and so far into the closet that he can't seem to find the doorknob, even though his mother and Aunt are doing all they can to help him. And I would think that any Mom and Aunt who have accepted their son and nephew's homosexuality and want to help him, would do a lot better to match him up with a regular guy than try to match him up with a room full of drague Queens and Leather S&M numbers.

The tour of the Gay Cure Clinic was funny, but again, a little over the top. Likewise the drague Queen hitting on the fundamentalist minister was amusing, but pretty unlikely. Unlike Torchsong, To Wong Fu and Priscilla, there is no clever or witty dialogue nor are there any great and memorable one-liners in this movie or any great and universal truths.

Over all, the entire movie, to me, is very amateurish and silly; it seems like something that might have been filmed in the 1970's. The mother and aunt seem to have much more fun hanging out with gay counter culture people than the son, who is so boring and uncomfortable with himself and anything gay, that he has already lost his first lover to another young man. It basically presents gay men as silly, vascillating individuals who spend their lives pretending to be women, pretending to be macho men and pretending to be happy. There are no middle of the road, well adjusted gay men in this movie; the kind that a mother or aunt would be happy to accept.
Plot as old as the hills and very poor acting by stereo type characters. Nothing here to entertain and nothing to see, despite the cover photo. Watch Big Eden instead.
I really enjoyed this movie! It was super corny, but extremely entertaining. I would definitely reccommend this to others! Just a couple more words are needed for this to be over with!!

When watching I had to laugh out loud several times, known cliches about gay people came all along. Especially funny were the mother's and aunt's roles when they tried to find out more about the gay scene (internet, gay bar).
I do strongly recommend it.

A fun little film about a mom's quest to find a nice guy for her gay son. The mom's heart is in the right place and silly mayhem unfolds.

Maybe a good rental for people who only want EPIC films in their private library...but a great little film which takes viewers on a fun adventure....none the less.

I got this film at a local video rental place.  What I thought I was getting was the foreign film Wild Reeds.  But when I looked inside I saw You Should Meet My Son.  I was disappointed to say the least until I watched the film.

Now I've watched with and without the commentary 4 times since last evening and I have just ordered this film from Amazon.  It is truly an amazing little low budget film.

There is something so genuine about the story, the characters and the actors.  On top of that, the film is simply FUN. It is hard to imagine Mae and Rose aren't actually sisters.  Their on screen chemistry is amazing.

I actually know of similar "fish out of water" experiences that played out in a similar way simply because the people involved are honest and good natured people.  That's what this film is all about.  It is a film where acceptance goes both ways, which is nice for a change.

Overall, the story is cute and so much fun.  The acting is good to excellent.  It is so easy to get caught up in the story that any evidence of "low budget" simply isn't noticed.

This is now among my favorite top 10 movies.

After having seen far too many gay independent movies that are promised/reviewed as being worthwhile (and finding out the hard way they're mostly not--for example most recently, "Is It Just Me?"), it's a relief to finally come across one that is genuinely wonderful.  I won't beat around the bush:  I loved "You Should Meet My Son."  It goes a long way towards making up for all the bad independent gay movies I've seen along the way.  It's a movie with a very big heart, and it's both funny and touching.  For whatever shortcomings there may be in the acting or script, they're largely irrelevant in the final analysis because the end result is so much greater than the sum of the parts.  It's not a perfect movie, but even still, it's extremely affirming, embracing, and rather touching.  I don't doubt this is a movie I will want to see again more than once in the future.  Congratulations to Keith Hartman (the writer/director) for a job well done.  Also, among the extras on the DVD are earlier short videos that Hartman made.  My favorite of the lot is "The Defenders" from 2009--it's fantastic and really funny, while also getting the point across rather potently.  You can also view "The Defenders" free on on YouTube.

This was a great little movie that my partner discovered.  You'll laugh and maybe even tear up a time or two.  The acting is very good, especially for an independent studio, and didn't feel forced or awkward at all.  This is one of those movies that a lot of gay youth wish would happen to them, and a few are lucky enough to experience.  I highly recommend the purchase to support everyone involved.  Also check out the writer's youtube channel at [...] for the trailer and links to several of his politically significant shorts.

I purchased this movie after reading the reviews and I must say I was extremely surprised that so many people had so many good things to say about a movie that had so little to offer. It was like watching a bad high school play. Both the acting and writing were on a pretty bland level. I would not recommend it at all.

Need a movie that makes you feel good?  This is it!  Gay comedy at its very best.  You will laugh out loud at the "not so funny" painful trials and tribulations of being gay.  This movie is packed full of stereotypes and cliches from both sides of the fence in a hilariously entertaining presentation.  Imagine Lucy and Ethel find out little Ricky is gay and they decide to get him a husband so he won't have to go through life alone and unhappy.  Wicked.
Love this movie. It is one of my favorite independent  Gay films. It is well acted, written and has a wonderful cast that makes you feel like that.
You Should Meet My Son is a solid indie film that is funny.  The acting was great.  I wish there was more to the story.  I wanted to see where the relationship with Chase and Brian goes.

Buy this movie!  You will laugh until it hurts.  Although produced on a small budget, the story and performances by the cast are at the top of their class.  It is the best gay-themed comedy I have seen.  I have viewed it several times and still laugh-out-loud at many of the scenes.

I had the privilege and pleasure of meeting the writer/director while this film was being showcased at our film festival.  At that time the film was not quite finished and it was great having him tell about the process and intent in various scenes.  I look forward to future projects created by him.

While not destined to become a classic, "You Should Meet My Son" is a wonderful, upbeat movie can will charm and delight its target audience.  The performances are all very natural and engaging. The plot, which other have already summarized, crosses into some very familiar territory (especially in the third act), but does so with a knowing nod to the source material which makes you realize that the producers were in on the joke.  Enjoy!

So I agree with some of the negative comments on this film, but it is difficult to deny the positive ones as well.  It is very overdone, and the acting isn't topnotch, however the reason this movie had appeal for me, is because you really do start to look at most of the characters and say- I wouldn't mind having these people as friends..  The mother's support for her son is also non-typical, but it is also something more mothers could aspire to, especially with current problems facing their lgbt children.

This movie is hysterically funny and yet touching as well.  An Alabama momma wants her son to be happy and, upon finding out he's gay when he breaks up with his boyfriend of five years, decides to help him find a mate.  First, she and her sister get a neighbor's teenage son to help them get on the Internet to look for men for the son (that scene was a real hoot).  Then, by going with her sister to a gay club, where the two old ladies met drag queens and leather boys, her neighbor's underage son again, a gorgeous stripper (who's an art student), and a host of other stereotypes from the bar.  So fish out of water, yet it works, kind of.  Then the son decides to marry the daughter of an anti-gay preacher and his wife and the story became a combination of "La Cage Aux Folles" and "Auntie Mame," as Momma had to rescue her sweet boy from the sharks.

I actually laughed out loud more than once in this film.  Touching scene near end when Momma assures her son how much she loves him "just like he is" and wants him happy.  I was lucky to have a mother with that attitude, but I know too many others are not so lucky.  Not a deep movie, not deeply moving or worthy of major screen awards, but not at all badly done and quite amusing (if highly derivative), and some really good eye candy in the supporting characters.  If you just want a light, fun evening with some laughs, this one will fill your bill.  Enjoy.

The only explanation for all the three and four star reviews is the director must have a lot of friends!  This is truly abysmal - like some gay amateur theatre improv exercise circa 1975.  The plot is painfully dumb, the characters defy human logic at every turn and the acting is beyond bad, but sadly not entertainingly so.  You've been warned!

I did not read much about this movie before I buy because I am collecting gay movies to study them. But it was a very nice surprise. It is fun, not very Hollywood movie, not very professional, but it is a great movie. It is very close to what is happening right now in many families not only in United States. It shows especially how some gay people do not go out because they do believe that the family will die after that. The movie shows how important it to have a good conversation with those who we love to explain to them how do we feel about ourselves.  I do recommend this movie to those who are afraid to talk about sexuality and gay diversity.
Very, very funny, but maybe to stereotypical for my tastes. Loved it when the mom and aunt changed. Loved the story. Maybe I just imagine it could be true.

I just LOVED this movie!!!  Really GOOD romantic comedies are not that common, and this film is certainly uncommonly funny, in my opinion.  As I watched it, the thought crossed my mind that some reviewers would call much of the movie stereotypical and cliched, but I didn't care!  So what?  The reason stereotypes and cliches exist is because they're true in life so while I'm not calling this movie "real life," it certainly has enough humorous situations and non-offensive funny characters that it kept me laughing out loud practically throughout the film.  I was caught by surprise that the son/nephew had decided to marry a girl to 1) please his family, 2) have children, and 3) avoid being alone in life, but the script writers dealt with that whole plot twist in a remarkably pleasing way, in my opinion.  I was glad that the religious-right (actually wrong, of course) characters were not overly demonized.  They were certainly "put in their place," but it wasn't really harsh and cruel like it could have been in a gay movie.  The movie was so bright, colorful, and filled with such extraordinary detail that I almost felt like I was watching a big budget or big studio film!  Congrats to all involved with this delectable delight of a film creation!  Of course it's NOT real, but what romantic comedy is?  It's not supposed to be!  Just enjoy!

Hilarious film about a confused family situation. Gay son tries to hide his orientation in order to give his mom what she wants, a happy hetero marriage with children. The plots and subplots unravel in very funny ways. Most of the characters are stereotypes and for a good reason as the film carries a message about respect, honesty and acceptance. It's a keeper!

This is a very sweet film worthy of your time and your money.  If you enjoy warm, light-hearted comic relief and can forgive a low budget, this film will not disappoint.

The scene with mum Mae and Aunt Rose on Manhunt is riotous.  An absolute scream.  I could not stop laughing.  Hilarious stuff.
"Ok.  Wow."
"Look at all of 'em."
"It...It's like a catalogue of men."
LMAO!!

Thank God this film is set in the South because of all the American accents the southern one is my favourite and makes this film an even bigger joy to watch.

I must say that as a start review it's my first the acting was a lot to be considered however the script made up for it, The one liners that appear throughout this movie click and would bring a smile to all i have already recommended it to friends for the fun and some great good looking guys It was fun and that is what makes a good evening with a movie

I saw this film at the Atlanta Gay Film Fest. and loved it!!  seeing it in a full theatre of like minded folks was wonderful.  So a few months back i wanted a great film for a movie night that my friends might not have seen....so I remembered this one and ordered it right away.  They loved it and they had a great time.

The premise is something that many people can relate to and that sucks them into the movie.

I have not laughed so much in a long, long time. This was a very well done film - great message, good acting, and interesting story line. I couldn't find this on Netflix and decided to take a chance on purchasing it based on all the great reviews on Amazon. It is definitely worth it!

The film "You should meet my Son" is a very low budgeted little film that many times is a very "Over the top" film with shades of "Auntie Mame" thrown in.  That said, I found myself laughing many times at the wild antics on the screen by all of the very good actors involved.  I particularly enjoyed the" in need of someone to love" son--played wonderfully and believably by Stewart Carrico.  He superbly plays a son "in shock" when his very conservative mom starts "match making" him with other gay men after trying very hard to match him with the "right" girl. In the process of finding a man for her son, she and her repressed sister meet some very "interesting" people and find some friends for themselves.  It's a fun "romp" for all.

Combined with a very amusing script and good direction, this film will make for a very fun evening. There is no violence, sex, nudity or much bad lanuage; therefore, anyone can enjoy this very funny "little" movie.

I love this movie for what it isn't just as much as I love it for what it is.  It's not another gay movie about a boy coming of age or a man coping with HIV.  It's a sincere and funny look at what could be just about any typical, loving family when it is confronted with the reality that anyone's child could be gay.  It is very well written with a great combination of simple humor and biting wit, while adding just enough camp to make it a blast!  It shines a comedic light on the often-ridiculous parts of both gay and anti-gay culture.  It makes you laugh and warms your heart with likable characters and a believable story.  I'd recommend it to anyone.

True to the DVD cover art, "You Should Meet My Son" doesn't masquerade as being anything other than light and fun entertainment, but it is also honest and passionate. In brief, a young gay man has tried far too hard to keep his sexuality secret from his mother and aunt - to the point where his partner leaves for greener pastures. Brian's mother and her sister discover the big gay truth and quickly dispense with their culturally acquired bigotry. They then set out on a mission to find heartbroken Brian a suitable gay male partner - taking a crash course in gay community diversity and etiquette in the process. However, thankfully, things are not that simple (and only marginally overladen with stereotypes).

Keith Hartman does a wonderful job with the script - keeping things fresh, lively  and relevant. Hartman also ought to take a deep bow as director in his first feature film - and he happily gives  plenty of due credit to the talented crew he assembled to make this film look consistently beautiful and interesting, and to also sound wonderful (especially, as we learn from the commentary tracks, in quite challenging circumstances).

The editing is particularly praiseworthy - my award goes to Donna Matthewson. The slightly surreal colours remind me very much of the UK original 1999 Queer As Folk series (NB: the cinematrogaphic quality is much better in this film - no doubt due in part to the advancements in digital technology).

The DVD extras are valuable - including Keith's short films in opposition to Proposition 8 (which excluded same sex couples from legal marriage in California). The only (minor) trouble I had with the DVD was in getting the correct commentary track to play - on two different brand players I could only get the one with the actors to work from the "extras" menu (no matter what selection I made), but by using the "audio" select on the remote I could also choose to hear the commentary by the writer/director and editor.

I recommend that anyone who likes the film (surely that's anyone who sees it) should also take the time to watch the film with each of the two commentary tracks - and then watch the film again with the original soundtrack. Your appreciation is significantly amplified, making "You Should Meet My Son" a film which you're likely to recommend to all your family and friends, and to enjoy re-watching  with them any number of times. An excellent original music soundtrack adds further lustre.

The cast all do a fine job and they must be very proud of the final edit. It's no surprise that this has been an award winner at gay and lesbian film festivals.

Brian is 30 years old and in the closet, or at least he is when he goes to friday dinner to his mother's home. He has a steady relationship with Dennis, who pretends to be his roommate. Brian's mother, Mae, is so out of the real world that she doesn't even consider the idea his son is gay until one of the candidate girl she brought to him doesn't enlighting her.

Here Mae's character, so as that of her sister Rose, turn into wonderful when they set out to find Brian the perfect husband, above all when his relationship with Dennis ends up in a bad way.

This is truly a movie about Mae and Rose more than Brian. I really like how Mae, not only understands what is better for his son Brian, but also tries to help other young boys, like she probably would have done for her son if he had the courage to tell her.

The supporting characters are all pretty good, I love the leather-couple, and Chase, the chosen husband, is cute with that big brownie eyes, and strange to say, he is even better when he is dressed ;-)

Aside from the jokes, this is a movie whose only fault is to try to do its best with the little budget it had. The plot is very good, the actors above the average, and the few sets carefully chosen. Sure, it shows the limited budget, but most of the time you forget it, involved as you are in the adventures of two middle-age women in search of true love... for their dear boy.

I really wanted to like this movie; bolstered by the good reviews here and a cute trailer, I decided to purchase it in order to support indie GLBT cinema.  The movie starts out promising, but quickly dovetails into a very bad and nonesensical remake of Auntie Mame (which one character lampshades (i.e., admits in the film)). The film devolves into a shrill whirlwind of tired jokes and stereotypes with far too much going on-screen.  Part of my disappointment also stems from a somewhat misleading title.  What I presumed to be a gay romantic-comedy from the title and trailer is nothing of the sort. This would be fine, but what exists as a plot insults the intelligence. Things happen for the sake of moving the plot along, rather than for any reason for those things happening.  Decisions are made with very little or no rationale or reason and none of the characters evolve beyond two dimensional cardboard cutouts.  I wanted a fun, light movie with a bit of a romantic edge; unfortunately, this movie has none of that.  My advice: watch Auntie Mame instead.

Director/writer Keith Hartman's charming comedy, about a mother's unconditional love for her gay son, quickly became an award-winning favorite at several gay film festivals. And it's easy to see why.
  At first, Southern mama Mae (Joanne McGee) is horrified to learn that her beloved only son Brian (Stewart Carrico) is "you know"...gay. Mae and Brian haven't been communicating at all. Despite the fact that he's had a five year relationship with his "room-mate" Dennis (Brett Holland) , Brian can't bear to tell her he's gay, for fear she'll need CPR. And if he can't tell her he's gay, he can't tell her he is heartbroken after Dennis leaves him. Mae learns the truth after her spinster sister Rose (Carol Goans) completes a gay quiz in "Glamour"  magazine. After some over-the-top wailing ("I should never have let Brian watch "The Wizard Of Oz"...it has Judy Garland") and a visit to an "ex-gay" church program, Mae and Rose decide they love Brian just the way he is. From then on, they are women on a mission...to find Brian Mr. Right.
  It is hard to believe that Mae and Rose are as clueless as they initially are... not only about Brian, but about everything! These women have never heard of the Internet. And they haven't been downtown in twenty years. Yet, the scenes of Rose and Mae's first day on the Internet and first night of "man-hunting" at a gay bar are absolutely hilarious. Rose takes a wrong turn at the gay bar and drag-queen Salsa (Matt Palazzolo) exclaims "Oh Grandma, "The Sound Of Music" look is so over!", just before giving her a mini-makeover.
  In this breezy 85 minute movie, the characters undergo some drastic and hasty behavioral changes. The movie itself also makes a rather dizzy transition from funny comedy to full-on farce in the vein of "Auntie Mame."  But, on the whole, the overall movie works. McGee and Goans give especially endearing performances. It also doesn't hurt that Stewart Carrico is gorgeous and easy on the eyes. The equally dreamy Steve Snyder plays Chase, the guy you  WISH Brian will get a clue about and hurry up and hook up with. The diverting ensemble cast also includes Ginger Pullman, Acquah Dansoh, Chris Nolan and Leif Holt.
  Keith Hartman's strength as a director/writer is that he goes for honest laughs instead of cheap ones. The humor is never at the expense of the characters. We laugh with the characters, but never at them. Hartman knows there must be humanity underneath farce in order for farce to work. The most touching moment occurs late in the film when Mae tells Brian, "I want you to be happy... and if you're not happy in this world, I will change the world. But I will not have the world change you!" That is the kind of unconditional,  loving response every gay and lesbian individual hopes to receive from their parents, friends, loved ones, etc., but seldom do. "My Son" presents the world as it should be, instead of how it is.  In this case, a farce-fantasy  is not a bad thing at all. The film offers hope and, with its head and heart in exactly the right place, is especially heartwarming.
